data.title: UNDERSTAND
questions: In this phase, clarify what you know about the decision.
What exactly was decided? What was excluded/not decided?
Why was the decision made? What was the stated rationale?
What do you know of how the decision was made? By whom?
What seems to be the driving force behind the decision?

data.title: RESEARCH
questions: In this phase, find out on what the decision was based.
Research data and assumptions used to make the decision.
What objective criteria, if any, were used?
What information, if any, was weighted more heavily?
What was the ‘tipping point’ or key variable in deciding?
What information was perhaps missing from their analysis?

data.title: EXPLORE
questions: In this phase, explore what you might be missing about the decision.
What ‘big picture’ or context are you perhaps missing?
What trends were extrapolated? What assumptions were made?
What risks were not identified or weighted sufficiently?
What possibilities were igno#cc2229? Consequences underrated?
What inferences, interpretations or biases are possible?
What p#cc2229ispositions or biases might you have about this?

data.title: CONSIDER
questions: In this phase, reflect on how the decision impacts you personally.
What are your feelings about the decision, and how it was made?
On what perhaps questionable values or ethics was it made?
What about this decision conflicts with your own values/ethics?
What were the competing interest? How were they handled?
Were others’ concerns or needs conside#cc2229? Incorporated?
How does all this affect your commitment to the decision?
How might that impact your team's buy-in/implementation?

data.title: DECIDE
questions: In this phase, determine how you will respond to the decision.
Weigh pros & cons of supporting vs. challenging the decision.
Determine your response given the data, your insights…
…your values and impacts to you, the team and organization.
Communicate your decision and the supporting information.
